title: At close of business on 29 July 2020, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 10 June 2020?
preds: No chatter at all about this changing.
Update for passing time. Reducing time spent for forecasting for a while.
it is very low and economy may suffer yet. Currently we will start earning season with hardly good news

Below are my reasons and weighting for each aspect i looked at: Complete Unknown (black swan event) - 10% split over each possibility knowledge and information gap - 10% split over each possibility Political - 4.5% same, 0.5% lower% - While the Fed is "Independent" I think that political pressure not to mention the ability to stack the board with political appointees makes the Fed not immune from politics. Trump has previously championed lower interest rates as well as called for negative interest rates. While firing the chair or tweeting about the chair wont change the bands. POTUS does have the ability to appoint 2 more governors and will only have to go through the senate (granted this would have to happen it hyper speed). POTUS also has the ability through policy to add to the debt which in turn could cause the FOMC to have to make a move.  Wild card - 10% split evenly - Given the state of the economy and the uncertainty surrounding the Covid pandemic we have seen the Fed say things like they have crossed red lines and tried new types of tools but most of all the Fed has mentioned they wont know what kind of effects these programs will have. Could the Fed go back to a single rate rather than a range? Could they abolish trying to manipulate short term interest rates and try to control long yield? I'm not sure, which is why I put this extra 10% of unknown I would usually keep out of my forecasts.  Other forecasters- 8.5% same 1.5% higher  - Using CME forecast + This Good Judgement project  FOMC - 35% same, 11.5% higher, 8.5% lower - Given the history of the meetings excluding emergency meetings. I see 60% of the time the rates stay the same and when there is a change in rate they tend to increase more than decrease.  While my bias is that the rate holds steady. Given the current uncertainty of a number of issues in the US (Covid, election year) i believe that if an unexpected event or situation came up I don't think paralysis would be an option.
Why would this close on June 10th? Looks like an error.
I could see them lowering rates further if things get worse.
The likelihood of a change seem to be decreasing with no major shake-ups resulting from re-openings

My first public forecast.... don't be kind rip it to shreds...Thanks First ill put Covid-19 aside for now. 
To do a "quick and dirty" I first reduced the question to "action" (Increase or decrease) VS. no "action" (stay the same). The Fed targets to meet 8 times per year, so if I  take the past 30 years that's 240 meetings. Of those 240 meetings 96 or 40% resulted in an "action". Of those 96 "actions" 57 were increases and 39 were decreases. 
Same = 60% Lower = 16.40% Higher = 23.60%.  This is my base rate I will be back with updates to this forecast. As I have not really gone "granular" yet on this.  Some questions that I will be exploring:
1. Has the fed ever raised or lowered the upper band without raising or lowering the lower band at the same time? ( I believe the answer is no to this one. But want to dig deeper)
2. could the fed go back to a single number rather than a range system?
3.The range system was created during the 2008 financial crisis, does it still serve its purpose?
4. The CME and other forecasters including the ones on here seem to have a consensus between 90%-100% there will be no change. How often have these forecasts/forecasters been surprised? That's just a few of the questions I'm looking at. I am also contemplating if asking the question of "will the fed go into negative interest rates" is a worth while question.  If anyone out there has any comments or suggestions I would like to hear them.
Negative territory is a wild prospect. I feel the Fed wants to keep that in their back pocket a while longer.

I previously was projecting some odds to lower in the case the FED tried to go below 0. Now it seems a) there isn't a lot of time to do such a unique thing; b) that the focus is on getting liquidity into the market to forestall liquidity crisis (done); and therefore c) they are waiting until opening or some kind of normalization before they begin anything new related to improving the economy.

Current target rate* is 0.00 - 0.25 (effectively ZERO). * Target rate was cut from 1.75 to 1.25 on 3rd March and then from 1.25 to 0.25 on 15th March (i.e a cut of 1.50% within 2 weeks) 2 more FOMC meetings are scheduled - 10th June and 29th July Chances are pretty nil that the Fed is going to increase the target funds rate (especially by July end - there is no need to do this). So, they cut to 0.00 in June and hold it in July           (July = June)    (20% chance)
Or, they hold 0.25 in June and cut to 0.00 in July      (July < June)    (10% chance)
Or they hold 0.25 in June and July                               (July = June)    (70% chance) I dont think a cut to 0.00 will happen (at least not by July). The Fed has been quick and effective in supporting the markets though, and they might keep up with such stimulus rather than cutting rates again.

Been at a 100 bet on this for weeks. I'm not a student of the Fed's voodoo, so I've been at the table at Vegas on this one. This feels like such a solid bet. Why would the FED get fancy over the relatively small 6 week window this bet covers. And with Nowhere DOWN to go, anyways!? It'll be no time to raise them, that seems for sure! With the exception of @Wildwood2000 I've seen no "dominantly" 0/100 betters do very well. He's the mysterious anomaly. I'd love to meet him someday! So I'm applying  (reluctantly, I admit.... but I'm trying to get better!) some of @Anneinak 's "Rules". Just a little bit :-)  Since I've had a couple of recent slaps (one a pure boner, one which I was generally just wrong about) , I'll reserve my ALL IN's for more judicious uses.

No reason to move off the lower bound for foreseeable future. Won’t go below zero.
Keep a little bit for the worse

The rate is currently almost at zero. It is very unlikely that the Fed will go into negative interest rate territory to stimulate the economy. However, the second-quarter numbers will be in on growth and unemployment so a later June date is more likely to be a change downward than the June 20 date. The economic outlook will be very bleak on Jun 29.

Markets give the FED a 100% chance of sticking with the rates. This seems most realistic given the options:
•	Raise rates: Seems impossible to do for Powell given following reasons: 
o	Economic forecasts for FY2020. Current earnings season proves the point 
o	Next rate meeting would be in the middle of next earnings season, it might well be that the US is then tentatively more open and feeling the worst is behind them. So outlook might be better. Yet, according to most recent IMF estimate the US economy will still be severely hit.
•	Lower rates: 
o	Lower rates would imply one of two things:
	A downward shift of upper and lower band. This would imply negative rates, which hurt European banks in recent years and even prompted hikes in Scandinavia, the US is very unlikely to follow the EU in this regard
•	A single rate (upper band = lower band): 
o	The FED did historically have a single rate which at current effective funds rate levels would mean a lower upper band
o	As of today, I see no indications anyone is discussing this

Prior to setting the target range in 2008, the target rate dropped sharply in response to the economic crisis that had just occurred. Similarly, the Fed recently dropped the range from 1.5%-1.75% to 1%-1.25% to 0%-0.25% in response to the economic crisis caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. Following the 2008 recession, the target range remained at the same rates for the following eight years. In 2016, the Fed raised the range from 0%-0.25% to 1%-1.25% as the US economy began recovering. Using this example, it is unlikely that the Fed will raise or lower their target range in the period between June and July 2020.
